SENT.plain: A patient with Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome was followed up for 24 years
The patient's parents were unrelated and unaffected
Facial dysmorphism was obvious as well as pectus excavatum, scoliosis, bilateral dislocation of the radial heads, hammer toes and hallux valgus, pes planus, arachnodactyly, and camptodactyly
He had a mitral valve prolapse
He was operated on twice for bilateral inguinal and crural hernia and several times for his foot deformities
At 24 years of age he was still thin, dolichocephalic, and the facial dysmorphic features were still obvious
Pectus excavatum was still severe but the thoracolumbar scoliosis was mild
His foot deformities had improved and his joints were less hypermobile
His main concern was the minimal subcutaneous fat and fragility of skin
